articles.headline: Obama Tells Republicans to ‘Reopen the Government’
articles.snippet: In a show of defiance that reflected Democrats’ confidence that conservatives had overreached, President Obama called on House Republicans to stop fighting his health care law.
articles.abstract: In a show of defiance that reflected Democrats’ confidence that conservatives had overreached, President Obama called on House Republicans to stop fighting his health care law.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama admonished House Republicans on Tuesday to quit fighting his three-year-old health care law and to “reopen the government,” a show of defiance that reflected Democrats’ confidence that conservatives have overreached after years of budget battles with the White House.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Why the Health Care Law Scares the G.O.P.
articles.snippet: The vehemence of the Tea Party aside, Republican efforts to derail the Affordable Care Act aren’t entirely irrational. It’s a threat to their party.
articles.abstract: The vehemence of the Tea Party aside, Republican efforts to derail the Affordable Care Act aren’t entirely irrational. It’s a threat to their party.
articles.lead_paragraph: This spring, the Missouri Chamber of Commerce urged the state Legislature to accept the federal government’s plan to expand Medicaid for the poor and disabled.

articles.headline: Austin, Tex., Stands Out in Hotel Recovery That Has Hugged Coasts
articles.snippet: In Austin, Tex., and in coastal markets around the United States, signs of a building boom are emerging as prices rise.
articles.abstract: In Austin, Tex., and in coastal markets around the United States, signs of a building boom are emerging as prices rise.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Skittish developers have delayed new hotels across much of the country until the economy returns to health, and financing does, too. But in Austin, developers aren’t that wary.

articles.headline: New York to Sue Wells Fargo Over Mortgage Settlement
articles.snippet: The New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, warned in May that Wells Fargo was violating a broad mortgage settlement, but the lawsuit comes after negotiations between the groups resulted in a standoff.
articles.abstract: The New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, warned in May that Wells Fargo was violating a broad mortgage settlement, but the lawsuit comes after negotiations between the groups resulted in a standoff.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fielding complaints from borrowers struggling to save their homes, New York’s top prosecutor is preparing a lawsuit against Wells Fargo, accusing the bank, the nation’s largest home lender, of flouting the terms of a multibillion-dollar settlement aimed at stanching foreclosure abuses.

articles.headline: Hollywood Advancing Clinton Film
articles.snippet: Though CNN and NBC both scrapped plans to produce projects about Hillary Rodham Clinton, “Rodham,” a feature film about Mrs. Clinton’s years as a young lawyer, is moving ahead.
articles.abstract: Though CNN and NBC both scrapped plans to produce projects about Hillary Rodham Clinton, “Rodham,” a feature film about Mrs. Clinton’s years as a young lawyer, is moving ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Two television projects about Hillary Rodham Clinton collapsed under political pressure this week, but she may yet get her close-up on screen, this time from Hollywood.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: Groceries Are Cleaning Up in Store-Brand Aisles
articles.snippet: Over the last three years, sales of store-brand products grew 18.2 percent compared with 7.9 percent for national brands, according to Nielsen.
articles.abstract: Over the last three years, sales of store-brand products grew 18.2 percent compared with 7.9 percent for national brands, according to Nielsen.
articles.lead_paragraph: Grocery store brands once carried a stigma. With no-frills white packaging that telegraphed bargain basement and low quality, they were a last resort for consumers on tight budgets.

articles.headline: Japan’s Nuclear Refugees, Still Stuck in Limbo
articles.snippet: Tens of thousands of evacuees from the area around the Fukushima nuclear plant are in emotional and legal limbo as the cleanup limps along.
articles.abstract: Tens of thousands of evacuees from the area around the Fukushima nuclear plant are in emotional and legal limbo as the cleanup limps along.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAMIE, Japan — Every month, Hiroko Watabe, 74, returns for a few hours to her abandoned house near the damaged Fukushima nuclear plant to engage in her own small act of defiance against fate. She dons a surgical mask, hangs two radiation-measuring devices around her neck and crouches down to pull weeds.

articles.headline: Google Accused of Wiretapping in Gmail Scans
articles.snippet: The accusations, made over several years in lawsuits that have been merged into two cases, ask whether Google went too far in collecting user data in Gmail and Street View.
articles.abstract: The accusations, made over several years in lawsuits that have been merged into two cases, ask whether Google went too far in collecting user data in Gmail and Street View.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Wiretapping is typically the stuff of spy dramas and shady criminal escapades. But now, one of the world’s biggest Web companies, Google, must defend itself against accusations that it is illegally wiretapping in the course of its everyday business — gathering data about Internet users and showing them related ads.

articles.headline: To Venezuelans, Heir of Chávez Is a Poor Copy
articles.snippet: Seven months after the election of President Nicolás Maduro, Hugo Chávez’s handpicked heir, inflation and shortages are creating discontent.
articles.abstract: Seven months after the election of President Nicolás Maduro, Hugo Chávez’s handpicked heir, inflation and shortages are creating discontent.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The start of the season for two premier teams in this baseball-loving nation was thrown into doubt after thieves stripped vast amounts of copper wire from the lights in this city’s main stadium. Basic items are often so hard to find that when a truck driver slumped dead at the wheel after a highway accident last week, motorcycle-riding looters swarmed in to grab the cargo: tons of red meat.

articles.headline: Justices to Weigh Key Limit on Political Donors
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court will hear arguments next Tuesday in a lawsuit challenging limits to the overall amount a person can contribute to all federal candidates in an election cycle.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court will hear arguments next Tuesday in a lawsuit challenging limits to the overall amount a person can contribute to all federal candidates in an election cycle.
articles.lead_paragraph: McCALLA, Ala. — The Supreme Court’s Citizens United decision reshaped American politics by striking down limits on independent campaign spending by corporations and unions. But it did nothing to disturb the other main form of campaign finance regulation: caps on individuals’ direct contributions to candidates.

articles.headline: Mutiny Halts Italian Gambit by Berlusconi
articles.snippet: Former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s attempt to resuscitate his endangered political career by bringing down the government instead provoked a rebellion in his own party.
articles.abstract: Former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s attempt to resuscitate his endangered political career by bringing down the government instead provoked a rebellion in his own party.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — He seemed stunned, if immaculately tailored in a dark suit that sheathed him like armor.

articles.headline: Loeb Raises Stake in Sotheby’s and Seeks Board Seat
articles.snippet: The activist investor Daniel S. Loeb disclosed that he is now the auction house’s biggest shareholder with a 9.3 percent stake in the company.
articles.abstract: The activist investor Daniel S. Loeb disclosed that he is now the auction house’s biggest shareholder with a 9.3 percent stake in the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: The activist investor Daniel S. Loeb said on Wednesday that he wanted to join the board of the auction house Sotheby’s and called for the chief executive to step down.
